headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff. Good morning, everyone. I'm glad you could join us today for Anadarko second quarter conference call. Today's presentation contains our best and most reasonable estimates and information. However, a number of items could cause results to d
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff. Good morning, everyone. I'm glad you could join us today for Anadarko second quarter conference call. 
Today's presentation contains our best and most reasonable estimates and information. However, a number of items could cause results to differ materially from what we discuss today.
You should read our full disclosure on forward-looking statements and our presentation slides, our latest 10-K, other filings and press releases for the risk factors associated with our business.  In addition, we'll reference certain non-GAAP measures, so be sure to see the reconciliations in our earnings release and on our website.  
We encourage you to read the cautionary note to U.S. investors contained in the presentation slides for this call and as we do each quarter, we have included additional information in our quarterly operations report as available on our website. And we'll be filing our water 10-Q for the quarter later this week. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jim Hackett, our Chairman and CEO, who will be joined by other members of our management team later in the call to answer your questions. Jim?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. We're pleased to report another solid quarter of operating results, and we'll now share the significant achievements and upcoming catalysts with you. First the highlights. We achieved record crude oil NGL sales volumes of almost
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. We're pleased to report another solid quarter of operating results, and we'll now share the significant achievements and upcoming catalysts with you. 
First the highlights. We achieved record crude oil NGL sales volumes of almost 300,000 barrels of oil per day -- excuse me 300,000 barrels per day, which resulted in significantly improved corporate margins and cash flow. We finalized the Lucius agreement, which further enhances the economic efficiency of this future megaproject. We successfully tested 3 wells at the Caesar/Tonga development, with each fill in rate of about 15,000 barrels of oil per day. we closed of the purchase of the Wattenberg plant in Colorado, which will improve recoveries and enable future expansion in the DJ Basin, including growth in the horizontal Niobrara play. 
The depth of the portfolio allowed us to direct capital investments toward areas that offer higher liquid yields. As a result of this focus, total liquids sales volumes for the quarter were 13% higher than the second quarter 2010, amounting to an increase of 3.1 million barrels. The increase in liquid volumes contributed to a 29% increase in adjusted EBITDAX per BOE over the same period last year. This margin expansion was enhanced by the widening differential between WTI and Brent, as more than 70% of our crude production is based on Brent equivalent pricing rather than WTI. 
Our record sales liquids volumes also contributed more than $1.8 billion in discretionary cash flow for the quarter. This cash flow covered our capital expenditures in the quarter, including a onetime investment of $518 million associated with the Wattenberg plant acquisition, while still generating more than $100 million of free cash flow.  Liquids growth was particularly strong in the Rockies. The Wattenberg field in Colorado delivered a 41% increase in liquids volumes versus the second quarter of 2010 and continues to set production records for the field. 
In the DJ Basin, we are encouraged by what we are seeing from our horizontal Niobrara program. We have significant running room of about 900,000 net perspective acres in the Denver Jewelsburg area, the majority of which is economically advantaged by our ownership via a land grant. The are focused on horizontal Niobrara opportunities in the DJ Basin, and we expect to add another rig to test multiple locations further north in the Powder River basin, where we hold an additional 360,000 net perspective acres. 
In the Greater Natural Buttes area of Utah, we set another fuel production record during the quarter, with average sales volumes representing a 16% increase over the second quarter of 2010. We're currently operating 6 rigs in the area and recently initiated construction out of a major pipeline and plant expansion that will increase our liquids processing capacity by about 250 million cubic feet per day. 
Additionally last month, the U.S. Department of Interior recognized and supported our collaborative efforts to address the Greater Natural Buttes expansion project. This is a significant step forward in the infill development of this area that offers tremendous resource potential with more than 6,000 identified drill sites that will provide sustained production and economic growth for the region. 
Moving to our Southern Appalachian region, liquids volumes increased by 24% with well volumes up 47% relative to the second quarter of 2010. In the Eagleford Shale, we increased gross sales volumes to approximately 45,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day at the end of the second quarter compared to 36,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day at the end of the first quarter 2011. We continue to be very active in the Eagleford with 11 rigs running. We achieved first production from 33 wells during the quarter and continued to improve drilling efficiencies and recently drilled a total of 20 wells, each in less than 10 days. 
In our West Texas Permian oil projects, liquids sales volumes for the quarter more than doubled over the same quarter in 2010. We've also continued to improve drilling efficiency by reducing our average drilling cycle times by about 20% or 7 days versus 2010. 
Turning to the Marcellus Shale in Pennsylvania, we're currently producing more than 500 million gross cubic feet per day from about 125 wells. Anadarko operates 7 rigs here, and we have safely reduced average rate cycle times by about 20% relative to last year. 
Now as an update on our megaprojects, we'll start to offshore Ghana at Jubilee. The partnership continues to ramp production toward capacity, which contributed significantly to our increase in our volumes during the second quarter. Current gross production is averaging about 80,000 barrels of oil per day. 
In Algeria, the project is nearly 80% complete. Construction of the central processing facility and its associated infrastructure is progressing, and the project remains on track for full facility completion in late 2012. 
At Caesar/Tonga in the Gulf of Mexico, we recently completed flow tests on 3 wells. Each demonstrated robust flow rates of approximately 15,000 barrels per day of high quality 27-degree API gravity oil. We're progressing 2 parallel riser solutions and expect to achieve first production in 2012. 
With unitization and expected of Lucius in the Deepwater Gulf of Mexico, we're eager to add it to our future list of megaprojects. As announced last week, we'll operate the unit with 35% working interest. Subsequent to the unitization, we also signed a production handling agreement, whereby natural gas produced from Exxon's Hadrian South deal will be processed with Lucius facility, in return for a throughput fee and reimbursement of all capital associated with the expanded gas capacity. This agreement will also result in higher natural gas price utilizations for the Lucius partnership to reduce transportation costs. 
During the quarter, we also completed a successful well test at Lucius. As designed, the well more than 15,000 barrels of oil per day of high-quality 29-degree API gravity oil. The test reinforced our previous resource estimates and indicated that Lucius can be developed with a minimal number of wells. The economics of Lucius were already very compelling, and the results of the flow test unitization agreement and the production handling agreement have elevated those economics to a higher level, making Lucius one of the most economically efficient projects in our portfolio. 
We've already begun ordering long-lead-time items including the floating trust facility that we designed with a capacity of 80,000 barrels of oil per day and 450 million cubic feet of natural gas per day. We expect to sanction this project later this year and are targeting 2014 for first production. 
Our offshore exploration appraisal program is accelerating significantly. We're embarking on one of the most active drilling campaigns in the company's history. Let me highlight the activities off the coast of West Africa. The drillship has just arrived offshore Liberia to drill the Montserrado prospect. Following completion of activities in Montserrado, we plan to move the drillship to Sierra Leone to test the Jupiter prospect and drill the first Mercury appraisal well.  We also plan to remain very active in Ghana and Mozambique, with additional drilling activities in Cote d'Ivoire, Brazil and China.  In addition, we expect to receive a permit to drill the Heidelberg appraisal wells soon and look forward to resuming an active program in the Gulf of Mexico. 
Turning to the financial results for the quarter. We recorded earnings of $1.08 per diluted share. As with previous quarters, we provided a breakout in the earnings release of certain items affecting comparability, without which second quarter net income would have been about $0.06 per share higher. Although we mentioned this earlier, it's worth repeating that adjusted EBITDAX per BOE increased by about 29% versus the prior year quarter and discretionary cash flow is very strong at $1.8 billion, generating more than $100 million
[Technical Difficulty]

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me try this. Let's start with the financial results and just about a little bit back. Just to repeat, we reported earnings of $1.08 per diluted share. And as with previous quarters, we provided a breakout in the earnings release of certain items aff
componenttext:
Let me try this. Let's start with the financial results and just about a little bit back. 
Just to repeat, we reported earnings of $1.08 per diluted share. And as with previous quarters, we provided a breakout in the earnings release of certain items affecting comparability, without which second quarter net income would have been $0.06 per share higher. 
And although, we mentioned this earlier it's worth repeating that adjusted EBITDAX per BOE increased by about 29% versus the prior year quarter and discretionary cash flow was very strong at $1.8 billion, generating more than $100 million of free cash flow after a onetime $2.5 million in the Wattenberg plant. 
We ended the second quarter with approximately $.4 billion of cash on hand in addition to the undrawn $5 billion credit facility, which has a term through 2015. We also entered in new hedges for a portion of our 2013 natural gas production to 3-way collars and this appears in the earnings release. 
As an update to the BP oil spill, we remain confident in our publicly stated position that we have not recorded a contingent liability associated with this event. We'll provide updated information on this subject in our forthcoming 10-Q. 
Looking ahead to the third quarter, we expect sales line to be in the range of 58 to 61 million barrels of oil equivalent. This reflects a risk operational profile that includes assumptions for downtime related to weather and facilities. 
In summary, we're very pleased with the performance of the portfolio in our quarterly results, and we're excited about the numerous significant catalysts in the months ahead. We look forward to updating you to on progress in the coming quarters. And with that, Jeff, I might ask you to open it up for questions.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And looks like our first question of the day will come from the line of David Heikkinen. [[Technical Difficulty] Let me go ahead and move on to Mr. Bob Brackett with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext:
[Operator Instructions] And looks like our first question of the day will come from the line of David Heikkinen. [[Technical Difficulty] 
Let me go ahead and move on to Mr. Bob Brackett with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: question related to Mozambique, twofold. One, that's an awful lot of core that you cut on the Windjammer and Lagosta. What were you targeting? And second on the Camarão, if I'm pronouncing that correctly. Is that targeting oil or gas?
componenttext: question related to Mozambique, twofold. One, that's an awful lot of core that you cut on the Windjammer and Lagosta. What were you targeting? And second on the Camarão, if I'm pronouncing that correctly. Is that targeting oil or gas?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bob Daniels here. On the core, we just cord the reservoirs that we have found in the previous discovery wells. And the idea there is to get really good petrophysical analysis of rock properties, so that we can put together our overall reservoir model and
componenttext: Bob Daniels here. On the core, we just cord the reservoirs that we have found in the previous discovery wells. And the idea there is to get really good petrophysical analysis of rock properties, so that we can put together our overall reservoir model and have a much better understanding about the flow units and fluids. We're going to get DSTs later in the year, to where we have a good idea about pressures communication, cobalt mineralization or not. And all ideas to get that data to a third party that can do a resource certification for us through 2012. So that's the idea. The analysis, the lab work on the cores takes the longest. So we want to get that up front. And because we got a very big project here, we want to make sure we got all the data that we need up front. As to the Camarão, it's not an oil project or prospect. That's in the same area, the LaBarge jammer area. And we're looking for an appraisal to the Windjammer prospect and also some additional sands that we did encounter in the original well. So it's an exploratory well from that standpoint, and then should be second half of the year here.

[Technical Difficulty] 
As you look at your exploratory program, I wanted to hit on the West African ongoing programs. First Ghana, can you talk about around extension of West Cape Three Points and any o fthe other prospects there first?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well again, David, this is Bob Daniel. On the West Cape Three Points, we've got an active exploration program going near. We're on the right now, which we used to call the updip Dahoma prospect. And of course, we've got the Mahogany East that we've alread
componenttext: Well again, David, this is Bob Daniel. On the West Cape Three Points, we've got an active exploration program going near. We're on the right now, which we used to call the updip Dahoma prospect. And of course, we've got the Mahogany East that we've already drilled and appraised. We have Teak as a the discovery and several other smaller discoveries in there. What we're trying to do in the West Cape Three Points block is to see do we have enough resources there that can be aggregated together to have another development. And of course, we have exploration and appraisal work done. We plan on getting back to Teak later this year for appraisal wells there. We also have the Centrale prospect that we'd like to get to. We had a rig lined up for it and had an issue with the previous operator, so we're looking at how we're going to get that well drilled. But there's still additional activity on the West Cape Three Points, all focused on do we have enough for another project there?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, those are the 2 in Cote d'Ivoire. And originally at the beginning of the year, we've said that we were going to drill 3 to 5 exploratory wells in West Africa this year. Then we dropped to 3, and that was because of the political situation in Cote d'I
componenttext: Yes, those are the 2 in Cote d'Ivoire. And originally at the beginning of the year, we've said that we were going to drill 3 to 5 exploratory wells in West Africa this year. Then we dropped to 3, and that was because of the political situation in Cote d'Ivoire. That's been settled. We can now operate in Cote d'Ivoire, where service companies are moving back in. Our offices are up and operating. We've come out of force majeure. We've contracted a rig actually to drill those 2 wells, so we'll start with CI-105 probably November's time frame. And then the CI-103, which is the Pon prospect will be followed thereafter immediately. So we have the first 2 slop on the rig that's coming. And we do expect at least the first one to spud this year and probably the second one to at least spud this year. good prospects in Liberia very similar to Jubilee style that we're pursuing, same target with the Cretaceous fan coming of this shelf. And we wanted to drill these wells for a while, and now we can.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Real quickly looking at your exploration slide for the offshore campaign. noticed the Gulf of Mexico Phobos is no longer on that list. Is there any particular reason for that? And then in the Gulf of Mexico, what would you kind of rank as your top prospec
componenttext: Real quickly looking at your exploration slide for the offshore campaign. noticed the Gulf of Mexico Phobos is no longer on that list. Is there any particular reason for that? And then in the Gulf of Mexico, what would you kind of rank as your top prospects for this year?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Dave, Bob Daniels again. Phobos is just off the list because of the timing that we're looking at 2012 spud for that, nothing to do with quality of prospect or anything like that. It's just as we look at which ones can we move through the system as the reg
componenttext: Dave, Bob Daniels again. Phobos is just off the list because of the timing that we're looking at 2012 spud for that, nothing to do with quality of prospect or anything like that. It's just as we look at which ones can we move through the system as the regulatory environment that we see, we need to get our present work done, the wells that we are already working on, such as Heidelberg. And then Spartacus looks like it's going to be an easier process. It's more straightforward. So we've been pushing that one as an offset to the Lucius discovery at the kind of separated off to the northeast. And we do expect to spud that either very late this year or early next year. So we have a very good inventory of prospects ahead of us. Phobos is one of them that if you look out into 2012, is on the list. Also try to put here is what's going to happen over the next 6 to 9 months.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great, I appreciate that clarification. And then looking at your efficiency gains in the Eagleford, Marcellus, Bone Springs specifically, can you talk a little bit about what that does as far as accelerating a drilling activity program there? And then how
componenttext: Great, I appreciate that clarification. And then looking at your efficiency gains in the Eagleford, Marcellus, Bone Springs specifically, can you talk a little bit about what that does as far as accelerating a drilling activity program there? And then how that impacts costs? Obviously it offset some of the costs inflation you're seeing. But aggregate costs, if you are going to be drilling more wells, could be going higher. Just trying to think about how that flows through the CapEx.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we're very pleased. This is Chuck. We're very excited about how our drilling teams performed in each one of those assets. They've done a spectacular job, actually getting more efficiency in every element of the well construction process. What we thi
componenttext: Well, we're very pleased. This is Chuck. We're very excited about how our drilling teams performed in each one of those assets. They've done a spectacular job, actually getting more efficiency in every element of the well construction process. What we think we're going to do, planning on right now, we're drilling more wells with the same rig count in the order of 40% more in several of these plays. And we're actually getting that many more wells drilled with the same effort, which gives us a much higher net present value for the production, because we get it on quicker. And it costs less to drill in the individual wells. aggregate CapEx is going up on a program basis in a given year because we are putting more tangibles in the ground. But our intangible costs are actually coming down. And so that all makes the economics better.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. I appreciate that. And then just one last one, if I can, with respect to the Wattenberg plant acquisition that's allowed you guys to increase liquids yield there and have great visibility on your running room for liquids production. Do you lo
componenttext: Okay, great. I appreciate that. And then just one last one, if I can, with respect to the Wattenberg plant acquisition that's allowed you guys to increase liquids yield there and have great visibility on your running room for liquids production. Do you look at making investments, pretty substantial investment on the liquid side of things in some of these other fields, like the Eagleford or potentially even parts of the Bone Spring, to be able to continue with that kind of similar visibility and forward projections?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're looking at each one of those carefully, and we have plans to maximize our revenues of each one of those fields. So additional wells and plants are under consideration in some level of progress right now.
componenttext: We're looking at each one of those carefully, and we have plans to maximize our revenues of each one of those fields. So additional wells and plants are under consideration in some level of progress right now.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I might mention too, Dave, I meant that we don't see an immediate need to do a big step out with capital on those infrastructure elements in those plays like in Wattenberg. That was a fairly unique situation. We had some very underwater contracts based on
componenttext: I might mention too, Dave, I meant that we don't see an immediate need to do a big step out with capital on those infrastructure elements in those plays like in Wattenberg. That was a fairly unique situation. We had some very underwater contracts based on a very old plant arrangement. And there's plenty of competition in these other areas for new infrastructure. And so I don't see the same kind of magnitude if you will.

componenttextpreview: Going to try a couple, if I may. Caesar/Tonga, given the delays to first oil, and the success you've had with the test results, is there any change to the development plan there? I seem to recall you were looking about 40,000 barrels a day through Constit
componenttext: Going to try a couple, if I may. Caesar/Tonga, given the delays to first oil, and the success you've had with the test results, is there any change to the development plan there? I seem to recall you were looking about 40,000 barrels a day through Constitution. But it seems that the field can do a lot better than that. Can you talk about?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Chuck. Actually we've drilled and tested all 3 wells now and in excess of 50,000 barrels a day per well. And what we have between Caesar/Tonga and Constitution is a minimum capacity of 40,000 barrels a day. So if there's upside opportunity on Cons
componenttext: This is Chuck. Actually we've drilled and tested all 3 wells now and in excess of 50,000 barrels a day per well. And what we have between Caesar/Tonga and Constitution is a minimum capacity of 40,000 barrels a day. So if there's upside opportunity on Constitution, we can push the rates up with the wells that we have. And we also have planned an additional well down the road, once we get the facility in subsea system, et cetera, wind down. With regard to the riser, we're progressing with 2 additional solutions, both of which have first production in 2012. And so we're on schedule to make that happen and to see that coming forward soon.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, so no change to the original plan, Chuck.
componenttext: Okay, so no change to the original plan, Chuck.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's right.
componenttext: That's right.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. My follow-up is first of all in Brazil, obviously you've laid out the 3 appraisal wells here. But what's the plan beyond that? I mean with these 3 wells, are you done in Brazil in terms of scoping and to scale? In which case, what do you see as a ru
componenttext: Okay. My follow-up is first of all in Brazil, obviously you've laid out the 3 appraisal wells here. But what's the plan beyond that? I mean with these 3 wells, are you done in Brazil in terms of scoping and to scale? In which case, what do you see as a running room there? And finally if I could ask you this, talk a little bit about Mercury. I guess a commentary in the release adjust that you'd be looking at DST there at some point. Can you just maybe give us an idea of what you're looking for there? What you think the ultimate scale of that asset could be? And perhaps what the plan going forward would be? Because I guess that seems the closest to moving towards development, or maybe I'm wrong there. give us some color there and I would leave it at that.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bob Daniels. On Brazil, we've got the 3 wells going. We're on it tightly right now. That's the first appraisal well of that discovery. So whether or not that's going to move us to a sanction point is we'll probably will need additional drilling after that
componenttext: Bob Daniels. On Brazil, we've got the 3 wells going. We're on it tightly right now. That's the first appraisal well of that discovery. So whether or not that's going to move us to a sanction point is we'll probably will need additional drilling after that. Wahoo, towards the end of the year, we'll be drilling the second appraisal well, second location really for appraisal. That could help us define what the previous DST and appraisal work, what we have there much better. And then Itauna which will spud start in September, remember that's a shelf discovery post-salt, potentially a simpler area, a simpler development, potentially a simpler reservoir system. And we try to design the program there that with very good news at Itauna, we might have enough to actually have confidence we can move that one forward. So that's what the appraisal's focused on. We'll need something else at the Taipu. Wahoo can help us a lot get to a decision point. And then Itauna potentially, with good news, could be enough. As to Mercury, when we put a DST in there, we've talked about it being Mercury as the most likely one. But we actually have the option to DST in West Africa any of the wells that we want to. so we're going to drill the wells and decide then what's the best place to run a DST based on the results.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Are you prepared to give any kind of idea of what you see as the scale of the opportunity there at this point? Or is it still too early?
componenttext: Are you prepared to give any kind of idea of what you see as the scale of the opportunity there at this point? Or is it still too early?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: We can talk about that in all of those. These are Jubilee style or Tweneboa/Enyenra style, which there are subtle differences between the 2, but overall the same Cretaceous fan systems coming up. It's where you are in that overall fan system. One, you're
componenttext: We can talk about that in all of those. These are Jubilee style or Tweneboa/Enyenra style, which there are subtle differences between the 2, but overall the same Cretaceous fan systems coming up. It's where you are in that overall fan system. One, you're down on the basin floor where you have more low bake type geometries. And other, you're up a little bit more in the channelized systems. And so the combinations of the 3 we're testing, we'll look at both of those. But we're looking at things that are the Jubilee and Tweneboa style and size. The scales are very, very similar when we look at these, at least the sand geometries and sand scale. We're looking at very similar size and scale to what we see in Ghana. So we're looking for multihundred-million-barrel-type objectives.

componenttext: Could I just squeeze one more then very quickly, Did the sequential drop in volume guidance Q2 to Q3, can you just quantify what you're assuming in terms of downtime, just in case we don't get kind of hurricane season? Or maybe you've priced then? And I will leave it there.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: We always have and will provide sort of a risk operational profile that's inclusive of what our historical weather patterns have been and the downtime associated with those, as well as what we anticipate downtime on our facilities around the world for pla
componenttext: We always have and will provide sort of a risk operational profile that's inclusive of what our historical weather patterns have been and the downtime associated with those, as well as what we anticipate downtime on our facilities around the world for plant maintenance and just normal outages. And you can see from historical performance that predictably, like in the last 3 years if you look through the second -- and sorry, the third and fourth quarter guidance, we hit it very well on a risk basis through time.

componenttextpreview: Can you spend a little more time on the Wattenberg Processing Plant purchase? How much more money you're going to put into it? And how accretive it could be, and when that accretion could start to show up?
componenttext: Can you spend a little more time on the Wattenberg Processing Plant purchase? How much more money you're going to put into it? And how accretive it could be, and when that accretion could start to show up?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Chuck. What we're seeing in Wattenberg, just a big picture, you step back kind of. The early returns on horizontal drilling campaign have been outstanding. And what we've decided to do is make strategic moves together, all the value chain we possi
componenttext: This is Chuck. What we're seeing in Wattenberg, just a big picture, you step back kind of. The early returns on horizontal drilling campaign have been outstanding. And what we've decided to do is make strategic moves together, all the value chain we possibly can, within Wattenberg inclusive of the plants, the gathering system, and land. And through that, we are going to put a very comprehensive development plan together, which includes the full utilization of all the plant assets we have out there, which now include the Wattenberg plant we just acquired from BP, the deli plant we acquired from cana and the facilities that we had, legacy facilities that we had at. So the combination of all of those, we think we can use to reduce our land pressures, increase our runtime and increase our recoveries both on our base production, which has historically been in Niobrara and Codell and adjacent wells and take full advantage of our horizontal program in the Niobrara, both inside Wattenberg and DJ.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And is it fair, financial question I guess, to say if I take that purchase out of the capital spending in the quarter, that I would add that to your $117 million of free cash flow, so the quarter really was -- adjusted free cash flow of $635 million. Is i
componenttext: And is it fair, financial question I guess, to say if I take that purchase out of the capital spending in the quarter, that I would add that to your $117 million of free cash flow, so the quarter really was -- adjusted free cash flow of $635 million. Is it fair to look at it at your company that way? That would appear to be a little early for Anadarko generating free cash flow. I remember thinking next year would be free cash flow, you're I know helped by $100 oil. But it appears to be free cash flow has arrived in quantity earlier than expected.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: You touched a little bit on the Niobrara. But I was wondering if you could give some more color with 15 wells now producing. Your thoughts so far, which is on horizontally and are producing, any additional color on what you're seeing.
componenttext: You touched a little bit on the Niobrara. But I was wondering if you could give some more color with 15 wells now producing. Your thoughts so far, which is on horizontally and are producing, any additional color on what you're seeing.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: As mentioned earlier, the early results look really good. And I think the uplift in our Wattenberg liquids volumes quarter-over-quarter, year-over-year, are indicative of the type of results that we're getting. We still think it's a little early in the ga
componenttext: As mentioned earlier, the early results look really good. And I think the uplift in our Wattenberg liquids volumes quarter-over-quarter, year-over-year, are indicative of the type of results that we're getting. We still think it's a little early in the game to come out and say, "Here's a," because we're exploring a very large area. As you know, we have almost 900,000 acres in the DJ Basin to look at. And so we're being methodical about our approach to evaluating that acreage. And then in addition, we're going to start a program in the basin, which is another 300,000 barrels so -- at 300,000 acres. So we have a very large area to evaluate. But again our early returns look really well, fairly good. And you're starting to see the result come through our flow volumes that we report quarter-to-quarter.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I guess what percent of the wells that you've drilled so far, the horizontal wells, are focused on the Niobrara zone versus the Frontier zone or other zones? And is there a way you could characterize of that 900,000-acre position, as what percent do y
componenttext: And I guess what percent of the wells that you've drilled so far, the horizontal wells, are focused on the Niobrara zone versus the Frontier zone or other zones? And is there a way you could characterize of that 900,000-acre position, as what percent do you feel like you've drilled and have confidence in are have a view that is repeatable in the absence of natural fractures?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Most of the wells we've drilled so far have been Niobrara wells. We are yet to drill -- we've drilled Frontier wells several years ago, but just about to start our campaign up in the Powder River basin here in the next couple of months. So the vast majori
componenttext: Most of the wells we've drilled so far have been Niobrara wells. We are yet to drill -- we've drilled Frontier wells several years ago, but just about to start our campaign up in the Powder River basin here in the next couple of months. So the vast majority have been Niobrara. We've actually tested a couple of other zones with 1 well. We're going to continue to evaluate the and others' potential as well in the DJ. As to what's perspective, if you look in the DJ Basin, about 200,000 or 300,000 barrels of -- I'm sorry, 200,000 or 300,000 acres of our position is in Greater Wattenberg, where we have 3,000 or 4,000 producing Niobrara wells. So we know it's very good in there. We've drilled wells with horizontals, and the early returns look very good. And we're out exploring. We've drilled about 7 or 8 wells or thereabouts, along with Industry, who's drilled another several dozen wells in the Greater DJ Basin. And some of those show very good potential for a very good economic return.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks. And then lastly following up on the last one, the previous question, the previous questioner, if Brent prices stay flat or strengthen from here, you'd be in a very good position from a free cash flow perspective next year. How do you look a
componenttext: Great, thanks. And then lastly following up on the last one, the previous question, the previous questioner, if Brent prices stay flat or strengthen from here, you'd be in a very good position from a free cash flow perspective next year. How do you look at capital allocation? Does that make you want to hold on to Mozambique versus seeking a partner? Does it make you want to accelerate exploration offshore, broadly deploy more rigs? How do you think about capital allocation?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Brian, in the past, we've identified our capital structure, keeping our debt to cap in that 25% to 35% range. And if we start generating free cash flow that would cause us go below that range, then obviously we've got a ton of opportunities around t
componenttext: Well, Brian, in the past, we've identified our capital structure, keeping our debt to cap in that 25% to 35% range. And if we start generating free cash flow that would cause us go below that range, then obviously we've got a ton of opportunities around the world. And we would continue to invest in those opportunities, because we think they provide excellent rates of return.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And do you see at all any constraints on the infrastructure side to ramping up in onshore U.S? And how that would compare versus an exploration ramp-up offshore internationally?
componenttext: And do you see at all any constraints on the infrastructure side to ramping up in onshore U.S? And how that would compare versus an exploration ramp-up offshore internationally?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well generally on the onshore assets, we're pushing really hard to expand our infrastructure position. Wattenberg is a great example of the new plants and the pipeline that we have taking in crude into Cushing. We've also expanded substantially our positi
componenttext: Well generally on the onshore assets, we're pushing really hard to expand our infrastructure position. Wattenberg is a great example of the new plants and the pipeline that we have taking in crude into Cushing. We've also expanded substantially our position in the Marcellus. And so each one of those are available to us. And as we get incremental infrastructure build-out, we can address them as what we have been doing.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011

componenttext: And just on the offshore international side as you might appreciate, I think we're in a good environment from a rig standpoint. mark are a little tighter on the spot market. But the spots as they almost weaken, we can do some things there as well.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Al Walker. A little bit on that. We certainly, like everybody else, have been watching the Middle East and North Africa with a lot of interest since the first of the year. We and Sonatrach entered into a formal arbitration process in Paris in June
componenttext: This is Al Walker. A little bit on that. We certainly, like everybody else, have been watching the Middle East and North Africa with a lot of interest since the first of the year. We and Sonatrach entered into a formal arbitration process in Paris in June. That concluded. We continue to have discussions around TPE. We're certainly open to ideas that could be independent of what that arbitration drive might decide later this year with a the ruling. We think our relations with Sonatrach, despite all of that, are excellent. At the PL level, we continue to have really good results. El Merk is progressing pretty much on track, with the expectations now of having things completed in 2012. and I'd say in general, the unrest in North Africa has certainly been a concern. We don't see any evidence of its impact on approximately 40% of the country's production that we operate, and hopeful the issues around TPE will get resolved by year and.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And only thing I'd add to that is if you'll recall, we had probably $7 a share taken out of our stock at a time the TPE was passed. It would amount to more than that currently. We don't think there's any equity value in there for a settlement or for a fav
componenttext: And only thing I'd add to that is if you'll recall, we had probably $7 a share taken out of our stock at a time the TPE was passed. It would amount to more than that currently. We don't think there's any equity value in there for a settlement or for a favorable decision. And so from our perspective, it's all upside from here.

componenttext: Yes, John, we're going through all the normal processes kicking off this LNG project. We actually issued contracts to start working through the scope and scale. I think what we're most excited about is the results from the drilling and appraisal program. our exploration Team, they found a tremendous resource. And we're going through the process the balance of this year and early next year to really size that up. And once we have definition around that, just how big it is and it looks fairly substantial, once we see how big it is, we'll start closing in on what the design parameters are for the plant, and then get into the actual process of feed and sanctioning that project in the 2013 time frame.

componenttextpreview: Bobby Reeves. Let me mentioned first, there's a lot more detail. It will be on 10-Q as we do every quarter. We'll update that disclosure in the 10-Q to be filed later this week. I will refer you specifically to that for details. But briefly, there was a n
componenttext: Bobby Reeves. Let me mentioned first, there's a lot more detail. It will be on 10-Q as we do every quarter. We'll update that disclosure in the 10-Q to be filed later this week. I will refer you specifically to that for details. But briefly, there was a notice of dispute submitted by BP under the joint operating agreement. We're in a process of time line, as provided under that agreement, to consider whether or not a resolution is possible. After particular time period, then either party can move forward with arbitration. We have not reached that time yet. And then that would invoke the time line for arbitration, which at the earliest would be sometime next year. With respect to settlement, we feel good still about our position that we've talked about for over a year now, but at the same time, remain open to discussions.

componenttext: this is Bob Daniels. Just on the rest of the wells, I touched on Heidelberg and Spartacus because those are the ones we operate. And we're moving those through the system. We have the most control over those. But our partners in other wells are moving and progressing very well through the regulatory environment. And that would include Quarnata and Yucatan over into the same mini Basin. Both are moving permits through the system. Vito, which is one of our discoveries that we have an interest in, the shell operates are moving permits through the system there. And we're presently involved with the tuner well, which is drilling. We have a carried working interest in that wells, so they have successfully obtained a permit on that. So while the process have been slow, people are getting excited about requirements are and the EPs and APDs are moving through the system. It just needs to move through the system on a quicker pace. But we do anticipate quite an active second half of the year in both operated and nonoperated wells and continue on into 2012.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, Jeff. Good morning, everyone. I'm glad you could join us today for Anadarko's second quarter conference call. Today's presentation contains our best and most reasonable estimates and information. However, a number of items could cause resu
componenttext:
Well, thanks, Jeff. Good morning, everyone. I'm glad you could join us today for Anadarko's second quarter conference call. 
Today's presentation contains our best and most reasonable estimates and information. However, a number of items could cause results to differ materially from what we discuss today.
You should read our full disclosure on forward-looking statements available in our presentation slides, our latest 10-K, other filings and press releases for the risk factors associated with our business. In addition, we'll reference certain non-GAAP measures, so be sure to see the reconciliations in our earnings release and on our website.  
We encourage you to read the cautionary note to U.S. investors contained in the presentation slides for this call and as we do each quarter, we've included additional information in our quarterly operations report as available on our website. And we'll be filing our 10-Q for the quarter later this week. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jim Hackett, our Chairman and CEO, who will be joined by other members of our management team later in the call to answer your questions. Jim?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. We're pleased to report another solid quarter of operating results, and we'll now share the significant achievements and upcoming catalyst with you. First, the highlights. We achieved record crude oil NGL sales volumes of almost
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. We're pleased to report another solid quarter of operating results, and we'll now share the significant achievements and upcoming catalyst with you. 
First, the highlights. We achieved record crude oil NGL sales volumes of almost 300,000 barrels of oil per day -- excuse me, 300,000 barrels per day, which resulted in significantly improved corporate margins and cash flow. We finalized the Lucius unitization agreement, which further enhances the economic efficiency of this future megaproject. We successfully tested 3 wells at the Caesar/Tonga development, with each filling in at rates of about 15,000 barrels of oil per day. And we closed the purchase of the Wattenberg plant in Colorado, which will improve recoveries and enable future expansion in the DJ Basin, including growth in the horizontal Niobrara play. 
The depth of the portfolio allowed us to direct capital investments toward areas that offer higher liquid yields. As a result of this focus, total liquids sales volumes for the quarter were 13% higher than the second quarter 2010, amounting to an increase of 3.1 million barrels. The increase in liquid volumes contributed to a 29% increase in adjusted EBITDAX per BOE over the same period last year. This margin expansion was enhanced by the widening differential between WTI and Brent, as more than 70% of our crude production is based on Brent equivalent pricing rather than WTI. 
Our record sales -- liquids volumes also contributed more than $1.8 billion in discretionary cash flow for the quarter. This cash flow covered our capital expenditures in the quarter, including a one-time investment of $518 million associated with the Wattenberg plant acquisition, while still generating more than $100 million of free cash flow. Liquids growth was particularly strong in the Rockies. The Wattenberg field in Colorado delivered a 41% increase in liquids volumes versus the second quarter of 2010 and continues to set production records for the field. 
In the DJ Basin, we are encouraged by what we are seeing from our horizontal Niobrara program. We have significant running room with about 900,000 net perspective acres in the Denver-Julesburg area, the majority of which is economically advantaged by our fee mineral ownership via the land grant. Running 3 rigs that are focused on horizontal Niobrara opportunities in the DJ Basin, and we expect to add another rig to test multiple locations further north in the Powder River Basin, where we hold an additional 360,000 net perspective acres. 
In the Greater Natural Buttes area of Utah, we set another fuel production record during the quarter, with average sales volumes representing a 16% increase over the second quarter of 2010. We're currently operating 6 rigs in the area and recently, initiate a construction on a major pipeline and plant expansion that will increase our liquids processing capacity by about 250 million cubic feet per day. 
Additionally, last month, the U.S. Department of Interior recognized and supported our collaborative efforts to address the Greater Natural Buttes expansion project. This is a significant step forward in the infield development of this area that offers tremendous resource potential with more than 6,000 identified drill sites that will provide sustained production and economic growth for the region. 
Moving to our Southern and Appalachian region, liquids volumes increased by 24% with oil volumes up 47% relative to the second quarter of 2010. In the Eagleford Shale, we increased gross sales volumes to approximately 45,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day at the end of the second quarter compared to 36,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day at the end of the first quarter 2011. We continue to be very active in the Eagleford with 11 rigs running. We achieved first production from 33 wells during the quarter and continued to improve drilling efficiencies and recently, drilled a total of 20 wells, each in less than 10 days. 
In our West Texas Permian oil projects, liquids sales volumes for the quarter more than doubled over the same quarter in 2010. We've also continued to improve drilling efficiency by reducing our average drilling cycle times by about 20% or 7 days versus 2010. 
Turning to the Marcellus Shale in Pennsylvania, we're currently producing more than 500 million gross cubic feet per day from about 125 wells. Anadarko operates 7 rigs here, and we've safely reduced average drilling cycle times by about 20% relative to last year. 
Now as an update on our megaprojects, we'll start Offshore, Ghana at Jubilee. The partnership continues to ramp production toward capacity, which contributed significantly to our increase in oil volumes during the second quarter. Current gross production is averaging about 80,000 barrels of oil per day. 
In Algeria, the El Merk project is nearly 80% complete. Construction of the central processing facility as an associated infrastructure is progressing, and the project remains on track for full facility completion in late 2012. 
At Caesar/Tonga in the Gulf of Mexico, we recently completed flow tests on 3 wells. Each demonstrated robust flow rates of approximately 15,000 barrels per day of high-quality 27-degree API gravity oil. We're progressing 2 parallel riser solutions and expect to achieve first production in 2012. 
With unitization and expected sanctioning of Lucius in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, we're eager to add it to our future list of megaprojects. As announced last week, we'll operate the unit with 35% working interest. Subsequent to the unitization, we also signed a production handling agreement, whereby natural gas produced from Exxon's Hadrian South deal will be processed with Lucius facility, in return for a throughput fee and reimbursement of all capital associated with the expanded gas capacity. This agreement will also result in higher natural gas price utilizations for the Lucius partnership to reduce transportation costs. 
During the quarter, we also completed a successful well test at Lucius. As designed, the well flowed more than 15,000 barrels of oil per day of high-quality 29-degree API gravity oil. The test reinforced our previous resource estimates and indicated that Lucius can be developed with a minimal number of wells. The economics of Lucius were already very compelling, and the results of the flow test unitization agreement and the production handling agreement have elevated those economics to a higher level, making Lucius one of the most economically efficient projects in our portfolio. 
We've already begun ordering long-lead-time items including the floating truss spar production facility that will be designed with a capacity of 80,000 barrels of oil per day and 450 million cubic feet of natural gas per day. We expect to sanction this project later this year and are targeting 2014 for first production. 
Our Offshore exploration appraisal program is accelerating significantly. We're embarking on one of the most active drilling campaigns in the company's history. Let me highlight the activities off the coast of West Africa. The drillship has just arrived Offshore Liberia to drill the Montserrado prospect. Following completion of activities in Montserrado, we plan to move the drillship to Sierra Leone to test the Jupiter prospect and drill the first Mercury appraisal well. We also plan to remain very active in Ghana and Mozambique, with additional drilling activities in Cote d'Ivoire, Brazil and China. In addition, we expect to receive a permit to drill the Heidelberg appraisal wells soon and look forward to resuming an active program in the Gulf of Mexico. 
Turning to the financial results for the quarter. We reported earnings of $1.08 per diluted share. As with previous quarters, we provided a breakout in the earnings release of certain items affecting comparability, without which second quarter net income would have been about $0.06 per share higher. Although we mentioned this earlier, it's worth repeating that adjusted EBITDAX per BOE increased by about 29% versus the prior year quarter and discretionary cash flow is very strong at $1.8 billion, generating more than $100 million
[Technical Difficulty]

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me try this. Let's start with the financial results and just about -- it's just a little bit back. Just to repeat, we reported earnings of $1.08 per diluted share. And as with previous quarters, we provided a breakout in the earnings release of cert
componenttext:
Let me try this. Let's start with the financial results and just about -- it's just a little bit back. 
Just to repeat, we reported earnings of $1.08 per diluted share. And as with previous quarters, we provided a breakout in the earnings release of certain items affecting comparability, without which second quarter net income would have been about $0.06 per share higher. 
And although we mentioned this earlier, it's worth repeating that adjusted EBITDAX per BOE increased by about 29% versus the prior year quarter and discretionary cash flow was very strong at $1.8 billion, generating more than $100 million of free cash flow after a one-time $0.5 billion investment in the Wattenberg plant. 
We ended the second quarter with approximately $3.4 billion of cash on hand in addition to the undrawn $5 billion credit facility, which has a term through 2015. We also entered in new hedges for a portion of our 2013 natural gas production through 3-way collars and this appears in the earnings release. 
As an update to the BP oil spill, we remain confident in our publicly-stated position that we have not recorded a contingent liability associated with this event. We'll provide updated information on this subject in our forthcoming 10-Q. 
Looking ahead to the third quarter, we expect sales volumes to be in the range of 58 to 61 million barrels of oil equivalent. This reflects a risk operational profile that includes assumptions for downtime related to weather and facilities. 
In summary, we're very pleased with the performance of the portfolio in our quarterly results, and we're excited about the numerous significant catalysts in the months ahead. We look forward to updating you to on our progress in the coming quarters. And with that, Jeff, I might ask you to open it up for questions.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Question related to Mozambique, twofold. One, that's an awful lot of core that you cut on the Windjammer and Lagosta. What were you targeting? And second, on the Camarão, if I'm pronouncing that correctly. Is that targeting oil or gas?
componenttext: Question related to Mozambique, twofold. One, that's an awful lot of core that you cut on the Windjammer and Lagosta. What were you targeting? And second, on the Camarão, if I'm pronouncing that correctly. Is that targeting oil or gas?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Bob Daniels here. On the core, we just cord the reservoirs that we had found in the previous discovery wells. And the idea there is to get really good petrophysical analysis, rock properties, so that we can put together our overall reservoir model an
componenttext: Yes. Bob Daniels here. On the core, we just cord the reservoirs that we had found in the previous discovery wells. And the idea there is to get really good petrophysical analysis, rock properties, so that we can put together our overall reservoir model and have a much better understanding about the flow units and fluids. We're going to get DSTs later in the year to where we have a good idea about pressures communication, cobalt mineralization or not. And the whole idea is to get that data to a third party that can do a resource certification for us through 2012. So that's the idea. The analysis, the lab work on the cores takes the longest. So we want to get that up front. And so because we got a very big project here, we want to make sure we got all the data that we need up front. As to the Camarão, it's not an oil project or prospect. That's in the same area, the LaBarge and jammer area. And we're looking for an appraisal to the Windjammer prospect and also some additional sands that we did encounter in the original well. So it's an exploratory well from that standpoint, and that should be at the second half of the year here.

componenttext: As you look at your exploratory program, I wanted to hit the West African ongoing programs. First Ghana, can you talk about thoughts around extension of West Cape Three Points and any other prospects there first?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, again, David, this is Bob Danes. On the West Cape Three Points, we've got an active exploration program going there. We're on [indiscernible] right now, which we used to call the Updip Dahoma prospect. And of course, we've got the Mahogany East that
componenttext: Well, again, David, this is Bob Danes. On the West Cape Three Points, we've got an active exploration program going there. We're on [indiscernible] right now, which we used to call the Updip Dahoma prospect. And of course, we've got the Mahogany East that we've already drilled and appraised. We have Teak as the discovery and several other smaller discoveries in there. And what we're trying to do in the West Cape Three Points block is to see do we have enough resources there that can be aggregated together to have another development. And of course, we have to have the exploration and appraisal work done. We plan on getting back to Teak later this year for an appraisal well there. We also have the Cedrela prospect that we'd like to get to. We had a rig lined up for it and then it had an issue with the previous operator, so we're looking at how we're going to get that well drilled. But there's still additional activity on the West Cape Three Points, all focused on do we have enough for another project there?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, those are the 2 in Cote d'Ivoire. And originally at the beginning of the year, we'd said we were going to drill 3 to 5 exploratory wells in West Africa this year. And then we dropped to 3, and that was because of the political situation in Cote d'Ivo
componenttext: Yes, those are the 2 in Cote d'Ivoire. And originally at the beginning of the year, we'd said we were going to drill 3 to 5 exploratory wells in West Africa this year. And then we dropped to 3, and that was because of the political situation in Cote d'Ivoire. That's been settled. We can now operate in Cote d'Ivoire, where service companies are moving back in. Our office is up and operating. We've come out of force majeure, we've contracted a rig actually to drill those 2 wells that will both start with CI-105, probably November-ish time frame. And then the CI-103, which is the Paon prospect will be followed thereafter immediately. So we have the first 2 slots on the rig that's coming. And we do expect at least the first one to spud this year and probably the second one to at least spud this year. They're good prospects, they look very similar to Jubilee style that we're pursuing, same target with the Cretaceous-age fan coming off this shelf. And we wanted to drill these wells for a while, and now we can.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Real quickly looking at your exploration slide for the Offshore campaign. I noticed the Gulf of Mexico that Phobos is no longer on that list. Is there any particular reason for that? And then in the Gulf of Mexico, what would you kind of rank as your top
componenttext: Real quickly looking at your exploration slide for the Offshore campaign. I noticed the Gulf of Mexico that Phobos is no longer on that list. Is there any particular reason for that? And then in the Gulf of Mexico, what would you kind of rank as your top prospects for this year?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Dave, Bob Daniels again. Phobos is just off the list because of the timing. We're looking at 2012 spud for that, nothing to do with quality of prospect or anything like that. It's just as we looked at which ones can we move through the system as the
componenttext: Yes. Dave, Bob Daniels again. Phobos is just off the list because of the timing. We're looking at 2012 spud for that, nothing to do with quality of prospect or anything like that. It's just as we looked at which ones can we move through the system as the regulatory environment that we see, we need to get our present work done, the wells that we are already working on, such as Heidelberg. And then Spartacus looks like it's going to be an easier process to move, very more straightforward. So we've been pushing that one as an offset to the Lucius discovery. The kind syncline separated off to the northeast, and we do expect to spud that either very late this year or early next year. So we have a very good inventory of prospects ahead of us. Phobos is one of them that if you looked out into 2012, is on the list. Also try to put here is what's going to happen over the next 6 to 9 months.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great, I appreciate that clarification. And then looking at your efficiency gains in the Eagleford, Marcellus, Bone Springs specifically, can you talk a little bit about what that does as far as accelerating a drilling activity program there? And then how
componenttext: Great, I appreciate that clarification. And then looking at your efficiency gains in the Eagleford, Marcellus, Bone Springs specifically, can you talk a little bit about what that does as far as accelerating a drilling activity program there? And then how that impacts costs? Obviously it offset some of the costs inflation you're seeing. But aggregate costs, if you are going to be drilling more wells, could be going higher. Just trying to think about how that flows through the CapEx.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we're very -- This is Chuck. We're very excited about how our drilling teams have performed in each one of those assets. They've done a spectacular job, actually gaining more efficiency in every element of the well construction process. What we thin
componenttext: Well, we're very -- This is Chuck. We're very excited about how our drilling teams have performed in each one of those assets. They've done a spectacular job, actually gaining more efficiency in every element of the well construction process. What we think we're going to do or are planning on right now, we're drilling more wells with the same rig count in the order of 40% more in several of these plays. And we're actually getting that many more wells drilled with the same effort, given with plan, which gives us a much higher net present value for the production, because we get it on quicker. And it costs less to drill any individual well. The aggregate CapEx is going up on a program basis in a given year because we are putting more tangibles in the ground. But our intangible costs are actually coming down. And so that all makes the economics better.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, great, I appreciate that. And then just one last one, if I can. With respect to the Wattenberg plant acquisition that's allowed you guys to increase liquids yield there and have great visibility on your running room for liquids production. Do you lo
componenttext: Okay, great, I appreciate that. And then just one last one, if I can. With respect to the Wattenberg plant acquisition that's allowed you guys to increase liquids yield there and have great visibility on your running room for liquids production. Do you look at making investments,  pretty substantial investment on the liquids side of things in some of these other fields, like the Eagleford or potentially even parts of the Bone Spring, to be able to, well, be able to continue with that kind of similar visibility and forward projections?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Dave, we're looking at each one of those carefully, we have plans to maximize our revenues of each one of those fields. So additional wells and plants are under consideration in some level of progress right now.
componenttext: Dave, we're looking at each one of those carefully, we have plans to maximize our revenues of each one of those fields. So additional wells and plants are under consideration in some level of progress right now.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I might mention too, Dave, on that is we don't see an immediate need to do a big step out with capital on those infrastructure elements in those plays like in Wattenberg. That was a fairly unique situation. We had some very underwater contracts based on a
componenttext: I might mention too, Dave, on that is we don't see an immediate need to do a big step out with capital on those infrastructure elements in those plays like in Wattenberg. That was a fairly unique situation. We had some very underwater contracts based on a very old plant arrangement. And there's plenty of competition in these other areas for new infrastructure. So I don't see the same kind of magnitude if you will.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Going to try a couple, if I may. Caesar/Tonga, given the delays to first oil, and the success you've had with the test results, is there any change to the development plan there? I seem to recall you were looking about 40,000 barrels a day through Constit
componenttext: Going to try a couple, if I may. Caesar/Tonga, given the delays to first oil, and the success you've had with the test results, is there any change to the development plan there? I seem to recall you were looking about 40,000 barrels a day through Constitution. But it seems that the field could do a an awful lot better than that. Can you talk a little bit about? And I've got some follow-ups please.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Doug, this is Chuck. Actually, we've drilled and tested all 3 wells now and in excess of 15,000 barrels a day per well. And what we have between Caesar/Tonga and Constitution is a minimum capacity of 40,000 barrels a day. So if there's upside opportunity
componenttext: Doug, this is Chuck. Actually, we've drilled and tested all 3 wells now and in excess of 15,000 barrels a day per well. And what we have between Caesar/Tonga and Constitution is a minimum capacity of 40,000 barrels a day. So if there's upside opportunity on Constitution, we can push the rates up with the wells that we have. And we also have planned an additional well down the road, once we get the facility in subsea system, et cetera, wind down. With regard to the riser, we're progressing 2 additional solutions, both of which have first production in 2012. And so we're on schedule to make that happen and you should see that coming forward soon.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, so no change to the original plan, Chuck.
componenttext: Okay, so no change to the original plan, Chuck.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. My follow-up is first of all in Brazil, obviously, you've laid out the 3 appraisal wells here. But what's the plan beyond that? I mean, with these 3 wells, are you done -- will you be done in Brazil in terms of scoping out the scale? In which case,
componenttext: Okay. My follow-up is first of all in Brazil, obviously, you've laid out the 3 appraisal wells here. But what's the plan beyond that? I mean, with these 3 wells, are you done -- will you be done in Brazil in terms of scoping out the scale? In which case, what do you see as a running room there? And finally if I could ask you this to talk a little bit about Mercury. I guess a commentary in the release suggested that you'd be looking at DST there at some point. Can you just maybe give us an idea of what you're looking for there? What you think the ultimate scale of that asset could be, and perhaps what the plan going forward would be? Because I guess that seems the closest to moving towards development, or maybe I'm wrong there. But now with the -- give us some color there and I'll leave it at that.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug. Bob Daniels. On Brazil, we've got the 3 wells going. We're on it tightly right now. That's the first appraisal well of that discovery. So whether or not that's going to move us to a sanction point is -- we'll probably will need additional drill
componenttext: Yes, Doug. Bob Daniels. On Brazil, we've got the 3 wells going. We're on it tightly right now. That's the first appraisal well of that discovery. So whether or not that's going to move us to a sanction point is -- we'll probably will need additional drilling after that. Wahoo, towards the end of the year, we'll be drilling the second appraisal well, second location really for appraisal. That could help us define now the previous DST and appraisal work, what we have there are much better. And then Itauna, which will spud in September, remember that's a shelf discovery post-salt, potentially a simpler -- well, it's clearly a simpler development, potentially a simpler reservoir system. And we try to design the program there that with very good news at Itauna, we may have enough to actually have confidence we can move that one forward. So that's what the appraisal's focused on. We'll need something else into Itaipu. Wahoo can help us a lot, get to a decision point. And then Itauna, potentially, with good news, could be enough. As to Mercury, when we put a DST in there, we've talked about it being Mercury as the most likely one. But we actually have the option to DST in West Africa, any of the wells that we want to. And so we're going to drill the wells and decide then what's the best place to run a DST based on the results.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Are you prepared to give any kind of idea of what you see as a scale of the opportunity there at this point or is it still too early?
componenttext: Are you prepared to give any kind of idea of what you see as a scale of the opportunity there at this point or is it still too early?

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: We can talk about that in all of those. These are Jubilee style or Tweneboa/Enyenra style, which there are subtle differences between the 2, but they're overall, the same Cretaceous fan systems coming off. It's where you are in that overall fan system. On
componenttext: We can talk about that in all of those. These are Jubilee style or Tweneboa/Enyenra style, which there are subtle differences between the 2, but they're overall, the same Cretaceous fan systems coming off. It's where you are in that overall fan system. One, you're down on the basin floor where you have more low-bake type geometries. Another, you're up a little bit more in the channelized system. And so the combinations of the 3 we're testing, we'll look at both of those. But we're looking at things that are the Jubilee and Tweneboa style and size. The scales are very, very similar when we look at these, at least the sand geometries and the sand scale. We're looking at very similar size and scale to what we see in Ghana. So we're looking for multi-hundred-million-barrel type objectives.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011

componenttext: Could I just squeeze one more in very quickly? The sequential drop in volume guidance Q2 to Q3, can you just quantify what you're assuming in terms of downtime, just in case we don't get kind of hurricane season? Or maybe you've priced then? And I'll leave it there.

headline: Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Doug, we always have and will provide sort of a risk operational profile that's inclusive of what our historical weather patterns have been and the downtime associated with those, as well as what we anticipate downtime on our facilities around the world f
componenttext: Doug, we always have and will provide sort of a risk operational profile that's inclusive of what our historical weather patterns have been and the downtime associated with those, as well as what we anticipate downtime on our facilities around the world for plant maintenance and just normal outages. And you can see from historical performance that it's particularly like in the last 3 years if you look through the second and -- I'm sorry, the third and fourth quarter guidance, we hit it very well on a risk basis through time.
